title: Moses' Final Charge
shortSummary: Deuteronomy 31 records Moses’ final instructions to Israel before his death, including the appointment of Joshua as his successor and the command to read the law regularly. It emphasizes God’s faithfulness, the importance of courage, and the consequences of Israel’s future unfaithfulness. This chapter sets the stage for Israel’s entrance into the Promised Land under Joshua’s leadership.
timeline: c. 1406 BC - Moses' final days before Israel enters the Promised Land

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The leader of Israel who delivers his final words and instructions before his death, preparing the people for transition.

keyCharacters.name: Joshua
keyCharacters.description: Moses’ appointed successor who is charged with leading Israel into the Promised Land.

keyCharacters.name: The Levites
keyCharacters.description: The priestly tribe responsible for carrying the ark and safeguarding the law, to whom Moses entrusts the written law.

keyCharacters.name: The Elders of Israel
keyCharacters.description: The leaders of the tribes who receive Moses’ commands and are responsible for teaching the people.

definitions.definition: The sacred chest that held the tablets of the law, symbolizing God's presence among Israel.
A sabbatical year every seven years when debts were forgiven and slaves freed, emphasizing mercy and obedience.
A poetic witness written by Moses to remind Israel of their covenant responsibilities and warn against future rebellion.
A visible manifestation of God’s presence guiding and protecting Israel during their wilderness journey.

outline.heading: Moses’ Announcement of His Death and Joshua’s Appointment
outline.description: Moses informs Israel that he will not enter the Promised Land and encourages them to be strong and courageous, assuring them of God’s presence. He publicly commissions Joshua as the new leader.

outline.heading: The Law to be Read Regularly
outline.description: Moses writes down the law and commands that it be read aloud to all Israel every seven years during the Feast of Tabernacles, ensuring continual teaching and reverence for God’s commands.

outline.heading: God’s Warning of Israel’s Future Rebellion
outline.description: God reveals to Moses that Israel will forsake Him after his death, provoking His anger and resulting in judgment, highlighting the seriousness of covenant faithfulness.

outline.heading: The Song as a Witness Against Israel
outline.description: Moses is instructed to write a song that will serve as a testimony against Israel’s future unfaithfulness, teaching the people and their descendants to remember God’s covenant.

outline.heading: Final Charge to Joshua and the Law Placed in the Ark
outline.description: Moses encourages Joshua to be courageous in leading Israel and commands the Levites to place the written law beside the ark as a witness against disobedience.

outline.heading: Moses’ Warning to Israel and Public Reading of the Song
outline.description: Moses confronts Israel’s rebellion and warns of future corruption after his death, then publicly recites the song to the entire congregation as a solemn reminder.

application: Trust in God’s presence and promises when facing uncertain transitions or challenges, just as Israel was encouraged to be strong and courageous.
Regularly engage with Scripture as a family and community to learn, fear God, and obey His commands, following Moses’ instruction for public reading of the law.
Recognize the danger of spiritual complacency and rebellion, and commit to faithfulness to God’s covenant throughout your life.
Encourage and support godly leadership in the church and community, praying for those who lead and trusting God’s guidance.

keyVerses.text: Be strong and of a good courage, fear not, nor be afraid of them: for the LORD thy God, he it is that doth go with thee; he will not fail thee, nor forsake thee.
keyVerses.significance: This verse offers enduring encouragement that God’s presence empowers and sustains His people in every challenge.

keyVerses.text: And he gave Joshua the son of Nun a charge, and said, Be strong and of a good courage: for thou shalt bring the children of Israel into the land which I sware unto them: and I will be with thee.
keyVerses.significance: God’s promise to Joshua underscores the importance of courageous leadership under divine guidance.

keyVerses.text: Take this book of the law, and put it in the side of the ark of the covenant of the LORD your God, that it may be there for a witness against thee.
keyVerses.significance: This command highlights the law’s role as a lasting witness and reminder of Israel’s covenant obligations.

keyVerses.text: And Moses spake in the ears of all the congregation of Israel the words of this song, until they were ended.
keyVerses.significance: The public recitation of the song serves as a solemn covenant reminder and warning to all Israel.
